meta.name: Praxia Skills Library
meta.description: Evidence-based skill definitions with prompts, examples, and research rationale

praise.name: Labeled Praise
praise.fullDescription: Labeled praise identifies the exact behavior you're praising. Instead of 'Good job!' you say 'I love how gently you shared that toy with your sister!' This teaches children exactly which behaviors earn positive attention.

research.finding: Labeled praise increases the target behavior by 30-50% compared to unlabeled praise.
research.citation: Eyberg, S. M., & Funderburk, B. (2011). Parent-Child Interaction Therapy Protocol.

prompts.hint: "I love how carefully you're building that!"
"You're working so hard on that!"
"Thank you for using your gentle hands!"
"You're being so patient waiting for your turn!"
"I noticed you shared with your brotherâ€”that was kind!"

good: I love how gently you're petting the cat.
Thank you for putting your shoes by the door.
You're being so patient waiting for your turn!
I noticed you used your words to ask for thatâ€”great job!
You're really concentrating on that puzzle.

commonMistakes: Using generic praise without specifying the behavior
Praising only outcomes instead of effort

reflect.name: Reflection
reflect.fullDescription: Reflection means repeating or paraphrasing what your child says. When they say 'Look at my tower!' you respond 'You built a tall tower!' This shows you're truly listening and validates their experience.

research.finding: Reflections increase child verbal output by 40% and strengthen the parent-child bond.
research.citation: McNeil, C. B., & Hembree-Kigin, T. L. (2010). Parent-Child Interaction Therapy.

prompts.hint: Child: "I made it blue!" â†’ "You chose blue!"
"You seem really excited about that!"
Child: "This is hard!" â†’ "That part is tricky."
Child: "Big truck!" â†’ "That's a really big truck!"

good: Child: 'Look what I made!' â†’ 'You made that all by yourself!'
Child: 'It's a dinosaur!' â†’ 'It's a dinosaur!'
Child: 'I don't like this.' â†’ 'You don't like this part.'

imitate.name: Imitation
imitate.fullDescription: Imitation means doing what your child does during play. If they stack blocks, you stack blocks nearby. This communicates 'What you're doing is important' and shifts the power dynamic in their favor.

research.finding: Parental imitation of child behavior increases positive affect and decreases oppositional behavior.
research.citation: Harrist, A. W., & Waugh, R. M. (2002). Dyadic synchrony.

prompts.hint: Build what they're building, draw what they're drawing
If they jump, you jump (if you can!)
Make the same sound effects they make

good: They stack red blocks, you stack red blocks nearby
They draw circles, you draw circles
They make car sounds, you make car sounds
They use the dinosaur, you pick up another dinosaur

describe.name: Description
describe.fullDescription: Behavioral description is like being a sportscaster. You narrate what your child is doing without evaluation: 'You're putting the red block on the blue one.' This shows attention and keeps you engaged.

research.finding: Behavioral descriptions maintain child attention and increase on-task behavior by 25%.
research.citation: Eyberg, S. M. (1988). Parent-Child Interaction Therapy.

prompts.hint: "You're putting the blocks together."
"You decided to use the blue crayon."
"You're thinking about where to put that piece."
"You're making the tower even taller."

good: You're drawing a big circle.
You picked up the red truck.
Now you're putting them in a line.
You're using lots of different colors.
avoid: Adding evaluation: 'You're drawing a BEAUTIFUL circle'

enjoy.name: Enjoyment
enjoy.fullDescription: Enjoyment is the heart of PRIDE. It means being genuinely presentâ€”putting away distractions, getting on their level, showing real interest. Children detect fake enthusiasm instantly.

research.finding: Parental warmth and attunement are the strongest predictors of secure attachment and behavioral outcomes.
research.citation: Ainsworth, M. D. S. (1979). Infant-mother attachment.

prompts.hint: Phone away, eyes on child, fully present
Get on their level, lean in, open posture
Genuine smiles, relaxed expression
Be genuinely interested in their play

good: Genuine laughter when something is funny
Leaning in with interest
Making warm eye contact
Relaxed, open body language

commonMistakes: Not getting on their physical level

respiroSteps.name: Halt
respiroSteps.instruction: Freeze. Do not react. Pause here.
respiroSteps.rationale: Stopping automatic reactions breaks the escalation cycle. Even a 2-second pause can prevent regrettable responses.

respiroSteps.name: Retreat
respiroSteps.instruction: Create space. Lower stimulation. Step back if needed.
respiroSteps.childInstruction: Hug yourself like going into a shell.
respiroSteps.rationale: Physical withdrawal reduces sensory input and signals to the brain that the threat level is decreasing.

respiroSteps.name: Breathe
respiroSteps.instruction: Take 3 deep breaths. In through nose, out through mouth.
respiroSteps.childInstruction: Smell the flower, blow out the candle.
respiroSteps.rationale: Slow breathing activates the parasympathetic nervous system, lowering heart rate and cortisol within 30 seconds.

respiroSteps.name: Reflect
respiroSteps.instruction: Ask yourself: What am I feeling? What do I need?
respiroSteps.childInstruction: How do I feel? What happened?
respiroSteps.rationale: Naming emotions engages the prefrontal cortex, which helps regulate the amygdala's fear response.
reflectionPrompts: What do I actually need right now?
What would help me feel better?

respiroSteps.name: Resolve
respiroSteps.instruction: Now you can think clearly. What's one small step forward?
respiroSteps.rationale: Choosing a next action restores agency and moves from reactive to proactive mode.

urgentiaScripts.name: Validate
urgentiaScripts.script: I can see you're really upset right now. That's okay.

urgentiaScripts.name: Early Prompt
urgentiaScripts.script: I notice your body is getting tense. Let's take a breath together.

urgentiaScripts.name: Offer Choice
urgentiaScripts.script: Would you like to squeeze something or go to your calm spot?
urgentiaScripts.when: Child is dysregulated but can still process language

urgentiaScripts.name: Selective Ignore
urgentiaScripts.script: Stay present. Don't engage with provocations. Wait for calm.
urgentiaScripts.when: Child is using behaviors designed to provoke

urgentiaScripts.name: Post-Calm Repair
urgentiaScripts.script: That was hard. I'm glad you calmed down. Want to talk about what happened?
urgentiaScripts.purpose: Reconnects and processes after the storm
urgentiaScripts.when: After child has returned to baseline
